section.title: What is AlphaDAO?
section.description: AlphaDAO provides Xbasic program access to SQL databases such as Microsoft SQL Server, Oracle, MySQL, and Microsoft Access. This functionality extends the familiar Alpha Anywhere database features that also supported .DBF files.
section.note: While not a part of AlphaDAO, it is important to note that you may also read SQL database data by creating passive-link tables. You may then browse these tables and make updates, open a form or report, and perform Xbasic commands.

section.title: Terminology
section.description: This document refers to SQL databases and tables as "back-end" databases and tables, and to Alpha Anywhere tables as local tables.

section.title: Goal of this Document
section.description: This document provides a few short examples showing how you can use AlphaDAO in your Xbasic scripts. In the examples that follow we will often show more than one way to achieve the desired goal.

section.title: Following the Examples
section.description: All of the examples in this document can be followed from Alpha Anywhere's Interactive window, or by creating Xbasic scripts. The examples all use the Alphasports.MDB Microsoft Access database. This database ships with Alpha Five V8 and is located in the c:\Program Files\A5V8\MDBFiles folder. If you want to work with data in a different database, the concepts learned from the example here will still apply to your database. section.title: The AlphaDAO Objects
section.description: AlphaDAO comprises many objects. You will use their properties and methods when you do your programming. section.title: Creating an Object
section.description: You can create an object by using the DIM statement. Afterwards, you will have to set one or more properties of the object, depending on its type and the context.
section.example: dim ti as SQL::TableInfo dim ii as SQL::IndexInfo dim ic as SQL::IndexColumnInfo ti.Name = "MyTable" ii.Name = "Primary_Key" ii.PrimaryKey = .t. ic.Name = "MyColumnName"

section.description: Frequently you will find a "child" object to be a property of a "parent" object. In these cases the "parent" object has already "DIMmed" it for you.
